debateinfo.title: CUSTOMS LEGISLATION (AUTOMOTIVE COMPETITIVENESS AND INVESTMENT SCHEME) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Moore, for Mr Truss, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.
The purpose of this bill is to amend the Customs Act 1901 and the Customs Tariff Act 1995 to implement two key elements of the government's arrangements for the automotive industry post-2000 by:
. reducing the rates of Customs duty on passenger motor vehicles and certain related componentry from 15 per cent to 10 per cent on 1 January 2005; and
. establishing the automotive competitiveness and investment scheme, ACIS, which will come into effect on 1 January 2001.
In so doing, the bill gives effect to the framework of assistance for the automotive industry announced on 5 June 1997 and 22 April 1998.
1. Customs Tariff Reduction

The rate of customs duty imposed on passenger motor vehicles, PMVs, and certain parts for PMVs by the Customs Tariff Act 1995 is presently 20 per cent. Under the current provisions of the customs tariff, the rate declines to 17.5 per cent on 1 January 1999 and 15 per cent on 1 January 2000, after which there are no further reductions. This bill will provide for a further reduction to 10 per cent from 1 January 2005.

The pause in the tariff from 2000 until 31 December 2004 will offer the industry a vital opportunity to prepare for subsequent trade liberalisation. This will occur as Australia meets its APEC commitments by the year 2010. The government and industry are both committed to the long-term goals of trade liberalisation. The progressive reductions that have been achieved so far, and will be continued to the year 2000, will maintain this forward momentum. At the same time, they will deliver cheaper prices and higher quality to consumers. The cut in 2005 will continue this downward pressure on the automotive tariff. This is consistent with the government's broader approach to trade liberalisation and is fully supported by the automotive industry.
2. Automotive Competitiveness and Investment Scheme

The bill provides for the establishment of the Automotive Competitiveness and Investment Scheme. ACIS will encourage new investment in the automotive industry as it strengthens its position as a self-sustaining, competitive player in the world market. The scheme will encourage investments by automotive firms in the physical and intellectual assets which will secure competitive advantage for the industry in the longer term. It will do so in a manner which, the government believes, satisfies Australia's international obligations.
The scheme is directed at the passenger motor vehicle industry. It is intended to encourage the development of competitive firms engaged directly in:
1. the production and assembly of passenger motor vehicles,
2. the manufacture of components and tooling and machine tools directly associated with such production, and in
3. the delivery of design, development, engineering and production services directly associated with such production.
ACIS will do this by providing assistance under two separate sub-schemes. The sub-scheme for passenger motor vehicle, PMV, producers will:
(i) extend the existing 15 per cent duty free allowance, DFA, earned on the production of passenger motor vehicles, PMVs, to 25 per cent:
PMV manufacturers will also be able to earn duty credits for the production of engines and certain engine parts; and
the allowance can be earned on production for all markets, as compared to the current DFA which is restricted to pro duction for the Australian and New Zealand markets only; and
(ii) enable PMV producers to earn a 10 per cent allowance on their investment in productive assets.
The sub-scheme for component manufacturers and service providers will provide benefits at:
(i) 25 per cent of the value of investment in productive assets; and
(ii) 45 per cent of the value of investment in research and development.
These benefits will also be available to PMV producers to the extent that they manufacture componentsâother than engines or engine partsâor provide eligible services for other parties.

All benefits under ACIS will be paid as transferable duty credits, and will be capped for each participating firm at five per cent of eligible sales in the preceding year to meet Australia's World Trade Organisation obligations.

In total, the additional entitlements under the ACIS scheme will be capped for the industry as a whole at $2 billion over the years 2001 to 2005. These do not include the existing entitlements under the DFAâ15 per cent on production of PMVs for Australia and New Zealandâthe continuation of which was announced by the government on 5 June 1997, prior to the government's decision to establish ACIS.
The bill provides for the administrative detail for ACIS to be detailed in subsidiary legislation in the form of regulations and ministerial guidelines.
3. Summary

This package is part of an integrated set of measures which will underpin the competitiveness of the automotive industry in the future. The two elements of the bill are complemented by the automotive market access and development strategy which was funded in the 1998-99 Budget. This strategy is directed by the Automotive Trade Council, which has representation from the highest levels in the industry.

It is vital that this package be implemented as a whole. It has the full support of the industry, which is committed to delivering major new investment, employment and exports under the certainty of the measures embodied in the package. Each measure is contingent on the success of the other, and it is essential that the integrity of the package be maintained during the passage of the bill. I commend this bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Martin Ferguson) adjourned.

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER(Mr Nehl) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: âA member of parliament's office is like a confessional. Every day, all of us see people who provide us with personal and confidential information. All of them should be able to have the confidence to trust in us that we will never, under any circumstance, reveal this information or identify those who provided the information. I was, therefore, somewhat surprised to hear, on ABC Illawarra radio on Tuesday morning, the member for Gilmore (Mrs Gash) reveal on air the income of a family who live in my electorate.

speech.para: In a live interview on the ABC on Tuesday morning, the member for Gilmore was spouting from the usual script provided by the government to defend the youth allowance. She had her go and then a few people called to give her the real life situation. Angry parents, none of them one bit sympathetic to the government's script, rang in to complain about the effect of the youth allowance. The member for Gilmore responded to one such caller by revealing on air what she said was the family income of a particular caller. The Edwards family, of Mount Warrigal, went public in their complaint about the member for Gilmore in yesterday's Illawarra Mercury under the headline, `Mt Warrigal mum: Gash got it wrong.'

Mrs Yvonne Edwards is a fighter, an ordinary Australian with a little fight in her, looking out for the interests of her son, and I commend her for it. Mrs Edwards is the woman who went to meet with the member for Gilmore to set her straight about the effects of the youth allowance, and for her efforts was dismissed as an `activist'.

But the member for Gilmore, on air on Tuesday, bit off a little more than she could chew. When Mrs Edwards disputed publicly that she had told the member for Gilmore what her family income was, the response from the member for Gilmore was that she was sure Mrs Edwards had told her the family income was over $60,000. I can say that Mrs Edwards, in her meetings with me, never once revealed what her level of family income was, and I never asked her.

Interesting questions need to be answered by the member for Gilmore. Where did she get this mythical $60,000 figure? Did she just make it up on the spur of the moment? Mrs Edwards says publicly that she never provided the figure to her, and I can say quite categorically that Mrs Edwards never mentioned any figure like that to me.

The member for Gilmore has caused the Edwards family some embarrassment, I believe, in making up figures and then throwing them around publicly. This is not the price they should pay because they had the fight to take on the youth allowance policy of the Howard governmentâwhich, as I remind honourable members, the One Nation Party leader, the member for Oxley (Mrs Hanson), supported and voted for. The member for Gilmore owes Mrs Edwards a public apology. She should provide that apology immediately. If not, I will continue to pursue her until she does.

I know how embarrassing it can be to have your personal financial details publicly revealed. Last year, during a bitter preselection battle for Throsby, someone, who should professionally have known better, made public details of my financial situation and touted around in public what my financial situation was and what my superannuation would have been, had I been defeated. So I share with Mrs Edwards the embarrassment of having financial details revealed publicly. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise today to discuss two important issues that affect my constituents: the National Competition Council and the full sale of Telstra. I have noted media reports that the President of the National Competition Council, Mr Graeme Samuel, is to undertake a tour of regional areas to explain the alleged benefits of national competition policy. I welcome that decision, however belated and overdue it may be. I wrote to Mr Samuel this morning inviting him to my electorate and offering to help arrange public meetings. He can be assured of a polite, if not enthusiastic, greeting.

speech.para: I have the most serious and fundamental objections to many aspects of this policy. I do acknowledge that in well-serviced, large urban areas there are benefits. But it is a recipe for disaster and economic and social devastation in smaller communities. In fact, the government recognised this by rejecting the National Competition Council's recommendations for Australia Post. If they had been adopted, rural and regional Australia would have been virtually isolated.

The time has comeâin fact, it is long overdueâfor the government to rein in what I have described as the scorched earth fanatics at the National Competition Council. They sought to strip postal services from rural and regional areas and were rejected. They sought to oppose the single desk selling power of the Queensland Sugar Corporation and were rightly rejected. Retention of this power was absolutely critical and fundamental for the steady and well-ordered progress of the sugar industry: I, my National Party colleagues and cane farmers bitterly resisted its removal and were successful.

If necessary, I am prepared to do battle with the National Competition Council on every single report and recommendation, in the interests of my constituents. They are not second-class citizens and understandably resent being treated as such. At the very least, there have to be exemptions from this scorched earth policy if we honestly want to do justice to rural and regional communities. Smaller local shire councils should be exempted from the crippling requirement of competitive tendering.

On a separate but related matter of defending and preserving services for rural and regional Australia, I wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) this morning, advising him that I would not support the full sale of Telstra. My reasons were contained in a letter, and I would like to quote from that letter. It states:

My electorate includes many small communities so you will understand that the people in them areâto say the leastâless than impressed by the so-called "customer service guarantee" that would allow a fully privatised Telstra up to six months to provide a telephone service to such communities with a population of between 200 and 2,500 and up to a year if the population is below 200.

There are a number of other reasons in my letter why I would not support the full sale of Telstra. My objections to the Telstra sale and my objections to the National Competition Council policy cannot be construed as disloyalty. My first loyalty is to my constituents. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI apologise to St Marys Senior High School in my electorate, because I have really been wanting to acknowledge them this year for some time. One of the pleasures of my life is to go along to St Marys Senior High SchoolâI had quite a bit to do with its establishmentâto their higher school certificate assembly.

speech.para: Again, 1998 was no different. There were 35 students recognised for excellence. To be recognised, they have to finish within the top 10 per cent in their subject in the state; some of them finished within the top one per cent or two per cent, and indeed one topped the state.

I would love to read out all the names, but I will not have time. I thought I would read out the successes of the dux of the school, Marnie Apieczonek. Marnie came to St Marys Senior High School from Mamre Christian College. A point I keep making to the Teachers Federation is that St Marys is actually reversing the drift.

In the 1997 HSC, Marnie gained top 10 per cent placings in 2 Unit General English, 2 Unit Mathematics, 2 Unit Chemistry, 1 Unit Applied Studies, 2 Unit Life Management Studies and 2 Unit PD//Health/PE. Marnie was also placed first in the state in 3 Unit Life Management Studies. Marnie intends to study Business/Law at the University of Technology, Sydney.

If I were to go through the results of all the students, you would find similar results. One of the great things about St Marys Senior High School is that it is a halfway house between the rigid discipline and force-feeding of students that you tend to get in the junior years of high school and the total responsibility that you need to accept if you go on to further studies at university or at TAFE, or when you go into the world of work where you need to accept responsibility for your own progress.

Having year 11 and 12 students studying at these senior high schools is, I think, very good for them. I notice the member for Namadgi (Ms Ellis) is next to me, and of course senior colleges are nothing new in the ACT. They have been working exceptionally well for the brightest of students or, alternatively, for those who see the world of work as where they would like to be. But in New South Wales itself St Marys Senior High School was the first ever public senior high. The establishment of Nirimba College has just been announced, and I hope within a couple of months that the establishment of Mount Druitt College will be announced. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise to bring to the attention of the Main Committee a matter of legal precedence in my electorate which I believe is quite alarming. Mr Deputy Speaker, the owner of a tavern in my electorateâcalled The Liars Saloon, of all thingsâwas the subject of a court case recently where damages were found against the publican for having served a Mr Rosser, who had spent, with his friends, some $400 on various cocktails and spirits in a few hours. Mr Rosser had organised for himself a chauffeur to take him home after this drinking binge. However, he got lousy with the chauffeur, grabbed the keys off him and drove home, had an accident and then took the matter to court, claiming that the publican was negligent. The matter was thrown out in the Magistrates Court, but when it got before a judge, Rodney Greaves, in the District Court, he upheld Mr Rosser's appeal and placed the onus and responsibility on the publican.

speech.para: My point here is that this decision in lawâand I hope it is appealed at a higher levelâsets some dangerous precedents throughout the community. What, for example, if Mr Rosser had killed somebody on the way home? Would the publican or the barmaid who served him be liable? What if we then take it further and say that somebody comes to our house for dinner and enjoys the ambience of the evening, goes home very drunk and maims or injures somebody? Is it then the fault of the host? I think this is a very dangerous precedent and one of the solutions that I am advocating is that all hotels acquire a breathalyser testing machine. I have rung Mr Lester Weston from The Liars Saloon in Victoria Park and he has told me that, since this incident, he has installed a breath-testing machine, but obviously it is too late after the event. From my point of view, Mr Deputy Speaker, I keep a mobile breath-testing machine in my car and make sure that I do not drive home after having lunch if I am over the limit. So that is one way that that can be done.

I think it does set a very wide ranging precedent. I think it is quite alarming that the law that is there to protect people and give people comfort, as has been said in an article in the West Australian, should defy commonsense. In this case, the judge, I believe, has set this dangerous precedent and I hope that at a higher level this matter will be appealed. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition

talk.start.para: âI want to talk about the level of disappointment I have at the government's decision to defund the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition, commonly referred to as AYPAC. In what can only be described as a very brief letter, giving what appears to be 12 formal days of notice, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) removed his government's support for AYPAC. The membership of AYPAC is not exactly what anyone could call a group of radical left-wing youth groups. In fact it represents a very broad spectrum of young people in this country.

speech.para: The membership includes groups like Guides Australia, Australian Rural Youth, the YWCA, the YMCA, Scouts Australia, The Boys Brigade, the Australian Young Christian Workers, the Australian Association of Police Citizens Youth Clubs, St Vincent de Paul, Uniting Education, the National Union of Students, the Australian Association of Adolescent Health, Kids Helpline, National Children's and Youth Law Centre, Fusion Australia, the Federation of Ethnic Communities Council of AustraliaâFECCAâand the youth affairs councils and networks in each state and territory. That is not a complete list but an indicative list of the sorts of groups that were able to get assistance and encouragement through organisations like AYPAC. The round table alternative which has been put up by the minister, with the greatest respect, I say to those who may participate in the future, is a very poor alternative.

What has been the role of AYPAC? Let us have a look. AYPAC is Australia's peak non-government youth affairs organisation. It has existed since 1991 and during that time it has received operational funding from the Commonwealth Youth Bureau in the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. AYPAC is a diverse coalition of youth organisations and networks. Members feel that AYPAC effectively represents their interests and concerns and AYPAC is highly membership driven. AYPAC promotes coordination in the non-government youth sector and amongst national youth organisations; it provides a valuable resourcing role to all youth sector organisations and disseminates information in relation to existing and planned government programs affecting young people.

AYPAC is a vehicle for providing comprehensive and constructive policy advice to the federal government. That is the key clause hereâ`comprehensive and constructive policy advice to the federal government'. I am sorry to say that I fear that some of the comments that AYPAC has made with the best of intentions as representing that body of membership is why it has got itself where it is today in relation to funding from this government. It is called shooting the messenger. This is a very bad policy decision made by this government.

AYPAC and its member organisations have extensive experience in promoting youth participation opportunities and offers leadership training opportunities for a whole range of young people right across this nation. I condemn this decision by the government and I call for the immediate reversal of the decision to defund the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition.

talk.start.para: âI rise to talk about a very exciting local youth project in my electorate of Dunkley, the Frankston Youth Health Service. This local initiative has been brought about by the community taking charge of the situation and listening to some of the concerns of the young people in my electorate.
âAnd helped by the local member.

âVery much soâsupported strongly by the local member. It began about a year and a half ago when one of the local general practitioners, Dr Nicky Martin, a person for whom I have great admiration, and a number of her colleagues, got together to establish a local youth health forum.

speech.para: That gathering was attended by a lot of people active in our community, and by a lot of young people, to talk about the sorts of concerns that were before the young people of the electorate. These concerns included how the health services available in the electorate were meeting their needs and what was the best course of action available to the community to make sure that the health services that young people needed were available in a timely and affordable way. What resulted from that excellent occasion was a commitment to establish a youth health service.

With the cooperation and the support of the Mornington Peninsula Division of General Practice, the Frankston Youth Resource Centre, the Frankston Community Health Service, the Peninsula Health Care Networkâwhich is the overarching body for the hospital and acute health services provided on the Mornington Peninsulaâmany of the local secondary schools, welfare organisations, local drug and alcohol treatment organisations and mental health service providers, the Frankston Youth Health Service was formed. The local police service and the state Department of Human Services also were very supportive of this idea.

Those people came together and provided the Youth Health Service through the local Youth Resource Centre. Fourteen local GPs provide their time on a roster basis and on a bulk billing basis so that young people can get the health service and health advice that they need without being worried that they are attending their family doctor and therefore worried about confidentiality issues and what might be discussed in a family health environment and perhaps being embarrassed as a result.

The Peninsula Health Care Network provides support with a sessional specialist paediatrician. The Monash Medical Centre's child and adolescent psychiatry department provides assessment and referral support. Local government is in there providing accommodation. The council has also assisted with resources. The Centre for Adolescent Health provides advice and guidance on the provision of services and planning for the future, and there is some corporate sector support.

This service has been so popular that it is effectively being overrun. The volunteer support structure that has guided this service and made sure that it has responded to the needs of young people is under pressure. I am working with those local health providers and the corporate sector to see what we can do to provide an Adolescent Health Fellow to support the program. I need to talk to the state health minister, Dr Rob Knowles. I have met with the federal Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge), and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has spent time with the people who are organising the program. I am hopeful of seeing this service improve in the future.
