subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 1 June, on motion by Mr Andrews:
That the House take note of the report.

talk.start.para: âI am very pleased to speak on the report entitled Don't stop the music! A report of the inquiry into copyright, music and small business . Before I get too far into this report, I would like to congratulate the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the fine job that it did in a nebulous sort of area. I would like to congratulate the committee chair, the member for Menzies (Mr Andrews); the member for Barton (Mr McClelland), the deputy chair; and all the other committee members. I am from Western Australia and, at the beginning, I would like to own up to the fact that I did not attend a lot of these hearings. The committee travelled across the whole country and I attended the hearings that I could in the House and in Western Australia. It was a very interesting inquiry.

speech.para: I make special mention of Judy Middlebrook, Claressa Surtees and the researcher, Natalie James. The area of the inquiry needed a lot of background research. I believe this is a big win for small business and it is one of the great things that this government has done. It has continually rewarded small business.

This inquiry and its terms of reference were sought because of the ridiculous situation that was developing in this country. The situation arose because small business people and small proprietorsâsuch as a hairdresser or barberâhad their radios on. Members from APRA, the Australasian Performing Right Association, and from PPCA, Phonographic Performance Company of Australia, went around and asked these business people to pay their licences for playing this music in their premises.

How ridiculous! A poor young hairdresser with a person in the chair had the radio on to break up the silent atmosphere. Because it was deemed that she was playing copyright music in a public manner, not only did she have to pay a fee but also there was a chance that she could be prosecuted if she continued to do so without paying her fee. I think it was a sensible move to have an inquiry on this matter so that it could be resolved. I will move on to how it was resolved shortly.

One of the concerns made to the inquiry was the fact that APRA in particular became pretty bombastic about the way it went about collecting this fee and intruding into people's businesses, trying sometimes in a clandestine way to find that somebody had their radio on. The worst part about it was that the poor person running this business was not aware that they were doing anything wrong. They had the speakers in the area and suddenly they were confronted by somebody from APRA saying, `Hey, you have not got a licence and you must turn that off, because if you don't we will prosecute you.' So it was a stupid thing.

Let me say, before I proceed any further, that we certainly must acknowledge and support the rights of the artists and the composers. They certainly do deserve to be rewarded for putting so much work into composing music, playing music and then having it recorded, et cetera. They deserve their remuneration for that. Nobody really discounts that. They discount the way that these people were being pursued for their licence fees and were not really aware of their rights.

I believe this is a big win for small business because, even though the fees were not large, it was something that they were not aware of and it was something else that was just annoying small business people. I just for the record say that the APRA fee for playing the radio is $37 and the annual PPCA fee to play a CD in your store is $47. That is not a lot of money, but it is a lot of time and effort if you end up in litigation because you did not realise that you were not meant to be doing this or you did not pay your fee on time or some such thing.

The sensible thing that came out of this inquiry was that in the first place APRA were quite adamant that they had a right to pursue in the manner that they were. They were rather convincing in some of their arguments. However, the beauty about this committee was that eventually APRA came back and in a voluntary manner decided that they would grant complimentary licences for businesses under 20 people. I think that is very good because it is just another imposition on business, especially small business, for somebody endeavouring to make themselves a living.
The first recommendation says:

The Committee recommends that the Australasian Performing Right Association and Phonographic Performance Company of Australia, in consultation with the Council of Small Business Organisations Australia and other relevant peak industry organisations develop an information campaign designed to educate the small business community about the law in relation to public performance of music and the obligations of those people who play music in public.

The first recommendation is a very sensible one. First of all, we are recommending as a committee that the small business people, through the business associations, educate the small business people about not only their rights but also their obligations.

Secondly, as I have already touched on, APRA came back and in a very sensible way came to the supportive view that they would issue complimentary licences to small businesses who play music in these areas. These were to be businesses employing fewer than 20 people.

Let me point out that this is a sticking point. My good colleague here from Eden-Monaro (Mr Nairn) also pointed out to me just a moment ago that, if the speakers are placed in an area, it does not absolve them from playing the music publicly. Recommendation 2 says:
. . . the general public and any performance inadvertently heard . . .

The key words here in the recommendation are `inadvertently heard'. If they deliberately turn on the radio, and appear to be flouting the generous complimentary licence, there is obviously some room to deal with them. But if they have a transistor, radio or CD player somewhere back in their business, and the music is being played as background noise, it is being inadvertently heard. This is the recommendation that we thought was being fair to everybody.

talk.start.para: âWhat about in a barber's shop type of thing?

âHave you been to a barber's shop lately, Mr Deputy Speaker, and had a haircut? We want to know which one. What I would like to say is that the concern is how this voluntary code is going to be endorsed. One of the things is that APRA formalised this approach in writing to the committee. I believe, and there is some argument to say my colleagues may even know better than Iâ
âIt's possible.

âCertainly very possible. I believe that if it is formalised in writing to a House of Representatives standing committee, it obviously is attracting privilege, et cetera and it would be quite remiss of anybody to have formalised this and then try to renege on their formal submission to a committee. I believe that gives quite a good guarantee to the industry that APRA is quite genuine in the way that it is approaching this voluntary code.

speech.para: The alternative is that the committee would have recommended legislation, and I think that could have been a far messier process than the voluntary code that was agreed to. But there still does exist, if this does not work, the opportunity to come back to the parliament and bring this legislation before the parliament to get similar sorts of outcomes to what we have got here. Also, the Department of Communications and the Arts will monitor APRA and will report to parliament in one year after this code has been in place. I think that that is another good check and balance on this whole process.

Finally, I would just like to point out another couple of recommendations. There was some criticism that there was still a parallel collecting between APRA and PPCA, but they do collect in two different areas so there certainly is an argument to continue collecting from two different organisations. One of the really good things that have come from this inquiry is that there would be a copyright tribunal which would have wide jurisdiction. What this does is allow conciliation before it ever gets to the courts. Rather than getting embroiled in a long and tedious court case, it allows there to be this non-legalistic tribunal which will sort out these sorts of matters with mediation, et cetera.
The committee also recommended in recommendation 6 that there would be a voluntary code of conduct for the copyright collecting societies, and I think this is also a very sensible outcome.

Finally, Mr Deputy Speaker, I was very pleased to be a part of the committee that came up with some very sensible recommendations that are not only good for the composers and the music industry, I believe, because it took a lot of angst and heat out of this situation, but also a big win, as I said initially, for small business. Thank you.

talk.start.para: âThank you. It is a very good report which confirms the value of standing committees' work.

interjection.para: Debate (on motion by Mr Sawford) adjourned.

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 1 June, on motion by Mr Andrews:
That the House take note of the report.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Chairman Forrest, your generous comments regarding the role of the committee system in the House of Representatives could give rise to a suspicion that you are chairman of one of the standing committees of the House.

speech.para: I am particularly pleased to have the opportunity to participate in this debate on Saving our census and preserving our history. This is actually a report from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, and in the last parliament I was privileged to serve as a member of that committee.

It is interesting to note that there has been speculation in the community over whether it is appropriate to retain census data and census forms beyond the period when they are currently kept. There is a range of reasons why various people have advocated that this should in fact occur.
The Treasurer (Mr Costello), being responsive to the mood of the community, provided to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs a reference as follows:
The Committee shall look at the current practice of destroying name-identified forms collected in population censuses and make recommendations for future censuses taking into account:â
. the effect retention would have on the quality, and hence value, of data from future censuses and other ABS collections;
. the privacy concerns relating to the storage and use of name-identified census data;
. the value of name-identified records for medical, social and genealogical research released after a significant period of time; and
. the cost of retention.

The committee conducted many public hearings throughout the nation. It is to the credit of the committee that it travelled the length and breadth of the country, to Adelaide, Brisbane, Canberra, Darwin, Hobart, Melbourne, Perth, Sydney and Wollongong. It received an enormous number of submissions, 291 submissions, along with a number of exhibits and very many form letters.

This matter clearly is an issue which has galvanised sections of the community who feel that the existing practice of destroying census forms after the data has been processed is not the appropriate way to go. However, there is no doubt that a lot of people resent the census and having to spend time filling in the forms. But it is important to recognise that government, and the community generally, does need the information which is derived from the census. So the question is not whether we should continue to have censuses but whether the forms should be retained for future use, and, if so, subject to what safeguards.

As one would expect, some parts of the bureaucracy were not in favour of retention of the material along the lines of what has been suggested. However, during its many public hearings the committee considered this matter and it has brought forward five recommendations. The first of these recommendations is:
The Committee recommends that name-identified information contained in forms from future censuses be retained.
The government has yet to respond to the five recommendations of the committee. However, I am hopeful that this first recommendation will be accepted by the government when the response is tabled.

para.inline: A division having been called in the House of Representativesâ
Sitting suspended from 11.33 a.m. to 11.44 a.m.

talk.start.para: âI was discussing the report entitled Saving our census and preserving our history before I was so rudely interrupted by the division in the House of Representatives.
âDisgraceful comment.

âI think it is an appropriate comment in the circumstances. I suspect that the honourable member opposite would agree, bearing in mind that the opposition were responsible for calling that particular division. Five recommendations have been made by the committee. Firstly, the committee recommends that name identified information contained in forms from future censuses be retained. The committee further recommends that specific legislation be implemented to provide for the retention of name identified information from all future censuses.

para.inline: A division having been called in the House of Representativesâ
Sitting suspended from 11.45 a.m. to 12.06 p.m.

talk.start.para: âThis is a multisegmented contribution to the debate in the chamber. I have outlined what recommendation 1 was of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Recommendation 2âthat name identified census records be closed for a period of 99 years and that no researcher have direct access to name identified records during that timeâis an important safeguard which, to a certain extent, tempers recommendation 1. Most of us will not be around in 100 years, and those of us who complete census formsâand we all doâwill not mind if researchers in 100 years time have access to that information. Personally, I have always had a concern that we are destroying our nation's future history when we destroy these forms. I believe that the recommendation brought forward by the committee in fact preserves the privacy of Australian citizensâwhich is very importantâwhile ensuring that future generations of Australians will have access to historical information which will be of very great importance.

speech.para: Recommendation 3 is that a stated purpose of the census be that name identified information be available for possible future research. That is all about accountability and telling the Australian community that this information will be needed for a certain purpose. Recommendation 4 is that during the 99-year closed access period the census records be able to be used by the Australian Bureau of Statistics for the purpose of certain epidemiological research. Access for the purpose of such research is to be strictly limited to applications put forward under protocols developed by the National Health and Medical Research Council. The applications must have received the prior approval of the ethics committee of the institution with which the researcher is associated. The committee further recommends that the NHMRC protocols take the form of disallowable instruments. That is yet another protection to the general community.

It is interesting that it has taken so long for a reference of this nature to be given to a parliamentary committee. It is my very strong belief that the recommendations which have been brought forward by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs are fair and balanced. The difficulty we have when we look at this question of privacyâand we have to compare and contrast it with the need for the community to have access to this information in the futureâis that we must achieve the appropriate balance.

I suppose that, in matters of public debate and public interest, balance is always important and the difficulty is in knowing exactly where to strike it. The report has achieved the correct balance, because the recommendations mean that, in future, we will retain the census formsâthat researchers will not have access to them for a period of approximately 100 years but that there can be some use for other purposes in the interim. So I see this as being a win, win, win situation.

It is a win for the community, in so far as we retain privacy safeguards. It is a win for future historians, who will be able to document the information contained on census forms. It is also a win for those people who need access to some of this information for other purposes. I am very pleased at the five recommendations and hope that the government will accept them. The government will take into account the full inquiry, the large public interest in it, and the submissions which were received from around the country.

I am confident that, given the fact that the particular reference was given to the committee by the Treasurer, at the end of the day these recommendations will become part of the law of Australia and in future we will not go on destroying records which will be essential to chronicle our nation's history. I commend the committee and I am pleased to take part in this debate, albeit in a number of brief segments.

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to support the report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the retention of census data. The committee worked very hard on this matter, and in particular the member for Cook (Mr Mutch) is to be commended for his work in so far as this inquiry is concerned. He worked very hard and his contributions to all of the committee hearings that I was involved in were of the highest standard.

speech.para: This is an inquiry that was overdue for Australia. We did need to examine a lot of the questions in relation to the census. The report has recommended that name identified information contained in forms from future censuses be retained. There are privacy safeguards, with the committee recommending that no researcher may have access to the records until the 100th year and that only officers of the National Archives and the Australian Bureau of Statistics are to process or handle census information.

That privacy safeguard is important. However, I would have been more inclined to lower the 100 years to about 60 years, because I believe that, in reality, that sort of time involved gives a more contemporary look at some of the trends and problems for our citizens. We may think of the movements of people over time, and we have the example of the terrible consequences for workers who worked in the blue asbestos industry at Wittenoom, whose situation would have been better tracked by the opening up of a more contemporary census for research and other purposes. I do not feel greatly uncomfortable with 100 years but I would have preferred that the period involved be lessâwith the appropriate safeguards.

Really, it is the research that is important. It is important to explain to succeeding generations that these research opportunities that are opened up by a liberalisation of examination of census data ultimately benefit the then extant generations and those coming on. We have heard a lot of evidence from many people about that aspect and also about the genealogical aspect, particularly in the Brisbane hearings which I had the honour to chair.

It is important to recognise what the committee has done and the fact that we need to change our view. But also we need to be very careful with information, including statistics. It is interesting that, according to the 1991 census, for example, a considerable proportion of people were not only below the poverty line but below social security entitlements.

The point I am trying to make is that this brings into question the accuracy of census information. It is a known fact, for example, that many peopleâin fact, a large proportion of peopleâdeflate their incomes in their census information, and many of them do not put figures in at all; so much so that it is arguable that either those income figures are basically useless or people are effectively not aware of what entitlements they ought to be getting, when you look at that particular example I gave.

It is also interesting to note that nearly 7Â½ per cent of people do not enrol on the electoral roll. So there are other factors in there in terms of census collection and we cannot be slavish adherents to those sorts of statistical data as well. We have to be very carefulâthere have to be factors and discounting involved. When we tend, as members of parliament, to quote figures from census documents, we tend to quote them somewhat unqualifiedly and somewhat slavishly, but we must remember those discounting factors.

There are a lot of people in my electorate, for example, who complained bitterly about the last census, who did think the forms were an invasion of privacy. I am aware of an instance as well where a particular person, who of course shall remain nameless, was very concerned about privacy questions. This relates more or less to the electoral roll rather than the census, but it is a related thing on privacy which obviously concerns people who fill in census forms. That is, that the people who enrolled on the electoral roll who had a very grave concern about their privacy did not know when they enrolled that that data could be sold to other agencies. Indeed, I inquired about this after a particular constituent complained to me and was informed that that was in fact the case, that the bureau could do that. Of course, people can be enrolled without their address. There are many people who do not know that, that people can enrol and ask to have their address private for the purposes of the electoral roll.

When it comes to matters of privacy, we have always got to be concerned. That is what this report has been quite concerned about overall. I have already mentioned the quality of the data, that we have to always be cross-checking. It is interesting to note, for example, that in the United States the census is every 10 years. We have it every five years. Maybe for those people who are concerned about the privacy aspects, their concerns might be assuaged if we looked at the timing of censuses. Maybe we should look at a longer time period, but a shorter period where that material can be opened up, such as 60 years, as I said before. There are ways of juggling it around that maybe can assist the privacy aspects but, as well, the research side of it can be enhanced. Overall, I commend the committee chairman, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews), and other members of the committee who participated in the inquiry. I look forward to seeing a comprehensive and competent response from government.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ted Grace) adjourned.

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 1 June 1998, on motion by Mr Andrews:
That the House take note of the report.

talk.start.para: âI was not a participant in the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, which has made this interim report on the Multilateral Agreement on Investment. However, this is an issue which has come to my notice, as I think it has to every member of this parliament, through the many requests for information that we have had and the many allegations that have been made by the public that this is a conspiracy against Australia. I want to blow that whole theory apart today. The reason for putting this on the public record is that I am very much determined to ensure that my electorate is aware of what this government has done to ensure that international treaties signed by this government are not signed until such time as the public has had its full say.
âOpen and accountable.

âOpen and accountable, as I am reminded by my honourable colleague. There has been to this date, according to the report, 792 submissions and some 380 form letters. There has already been one lot of evidence taken here in Canberra, and that process will continue, with individuals from the public being able to make submissions and give evidence to this committee, right around Australia. The information is available on the Internet. It has been advertised widely. When people ring my offices and say, `I did not see the advertisements,' I would like to state here on the public record, as per paragraph 1.9:

speech.para: The inquiry was advertised in the Australian Financial Review on Friday 13 March 1998 and in the following newspapers on Saturday 14 March 1998: The Weekend Australian, Adelaide Advertiser, Brisbane Courier-Mail, Launceston Examiner, Canberra Times, Centralian Advocate, Northern Territory News, Hobart Mercury, Melbourne Age, West Australian and the Sydney Morning Herald . Submissions were called for by 30 April 1998.

Whenever people have contacted my office on this issue, we have given them full and frank advice about where the government is on this matter, and where the process is going, and how they can have a role. And yet, having given all of these opportunities, having directed them to the Internet, we still find that they come back and say to us: `This has been done in secret. You people are trying to sell the Australian family jewels. You are trying to give away Australia's sovereignty.' I refer to paragraph 1.22 in this report. It states:
Consultation underpins these reforms, and the Committee reiterates the parameters set out by the Minister.
That is the minister of this federal coalition government, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer). It states:

[These measures] will also ensure that every Australian individual and interest group with a concern about treaty issues has the opportunity to make that concern known. Consultation will be the key word, and the Government will not act to ratify a treaty unless it is able to assure itself that the treaty action proposed is supported by national interest considerations.

There could be no clearer way to ensure that this must be in every Australian's best interest before this government will sign up to it. The very thought that we, as a responsible government and as a community which exports billions of dollars worth of goods and services every year, should not participate in international negotiation is foolhardy in the extreme.

The recommendations of this committee are quite simple: that Australia not sign the final text of the Multilateral Agreement on Investment unless and until a thorough assessment has been made of the national interest and a decision made that it is in Australia's interest to do so, and that the committee continue its public inquiry into the MAI and provide a full report to parliament at a later date.

I do not know what more we, as a parliament, can do for the people other than to take their advice, to listen to them, to go out into the various capital cities and regional centres of Australia, and to allow them to come and sit before an inquiry and give their concerns. Further in this report it states that the committee was very disappointed, to say the least, in what the bureaucracy has brought forward. I think that this is what we, as parliamentarians, must draw out of our bureaucracy if we are to protect the interests of our Australian constituencies. It is not good enough for the bureaucracy to simply stonewall, or give inadequate information, and expect the parliament to run away and deal with it.

The public expect more from us. They expect us to question our bureaucracy to ensure that we are getting from them the level of information that we require, and that it is in the best interests of Australia. The report does not shy away from the fact that we have been disappointed, or that the members of this committee have been disappointed, particularly with Treasury, and, therefore, it is important that this process continue so that the complete reportâthis only being the interimâon the Multilateral Agreement on Investment, in fact, does spell out the full picture.

From my own point of view, I put it on the public record that I do not support any agreement which is not in the fullest interest of Australia. There is nothing at this stage to indicate that this agreement here does that. I will rely on my parliamentary colleagues from all parties representing the constituents of Australia. I will also rely on the integrity of those people who will come before this committee over the coming months and give their evidence so that those wide ranging views of Australians will be taken into account. We will not simply rely on the bureaucracy to ensure that we get the best outcome. The parliament will play its role. The constituents and the constituency of Australia, the average man in the street, can have their opportunity to have their say and play a role to ensure that if any multilateral agreement, or any other international agreement, is signed by this country, its first and primary role must be in the best interests of Australia.

I do not believe that that has been the case in every instance in the past and that is why the public are upset. The public say that for too long too many of these agreements were signed without their knowledge and that was true. This government has moved to ensure that this is an inclusive process, so all Australians have their say.

I commend the work of the committee. I commend all of those Australians, some of whom I must say hold some very odd views in relation to secrecy and conspiracies, because a conspiracy to me is when you actually withhold information and send out the wrong picture. This is allowing everyone to be involved wholeheartedly. I encourage them to do so over the coming months and I am sure that the minister will listen to the report that comes down. I look forward to the opportunity of debating it further when the final report is adopted here in parliament.

talk.start.para: âThere is a much overused saying in Australia. I cannot use the unparliamentary word, but I will amend it. The saying is: give them the mushroom treatment, keep them in the dark and feed them bulldust. I think people will know what the unparliamentary word may have been. In regard to the interim report on the Multilateral Agreement on Investment, many Australians would probably say just that.

speech.para: One of the problems that we encountered on the committeeâand I am sure I can speak for many members in this House as having encountered itâis that something has crept up on us. Suddenly we find people coming out with conspiracy theories that the member for Longman (Mr Brough) mentioned because something has suddenly crept up on us. Not all of us or all our constituents read Hansard. The only ones who do probably are those who need cures for insomnia or something like that. The fact is that this thing did creep up on people and the bureaucracy and business were giving it a big tick.

I am sure the member for Moreton (Mr Hardgrave) will remember the day down here in Canberra hearings when, through perseverance and erudite questioning, we made some Treasury officials quite uncomfortable. Furthermore, I felt there was an element of arrogance attached to the representative from business. I am not quite sure of the name. It was the Australian Chamber of Commerce, I believe, but I am not 100 per cent sure. But there was an element of arrogance attached to his evidenceâhow dare we and the people of Australia question this thing?

One of the questions I raised in relation to the treatyâand I do not know whether it has been ever answeredâwas whether or not under the treaty it was possible for a multinational corporation to employ child labour in a particular area and be untouched by the government which would be the recipient of that child labour? In other words, if Australia wanted to impose a ban on soccer balls that were being made by children in India, if this thing was in place, could it stop the Australian government from taking measures to prevent that material being imported into this country? That is a very significant question.

I hate using the word `globalisation' because I do not think anybody really knows what it means, except that it is frightening and mostly to the constituents that you talk to about it. But the fact is that this is a sort of masterpiece of globalisation and it is something that has not just been thought of yesterday. It has been in its genesis and embryonic stage for a long period of time. You try and get a copy of it. A constituent of mine who regularly calls me about many issues did try to get a copy of the particular draft. It was almost impossible. He was told that it was something like 700 or 800 pages long.

On the aspect of conspiracies and being concerned, I do not blame individuals for being concerned. I do not blame individuals for saying, `Look, this is yet another conspiracy,' because when they look at the recent history in relationâ(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being 12.30 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Main Committee do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âThis week members would have received this document from the St Vincent de Paul Society entitled In defence of the bush . The statement gives examples of how government policies, closures in essential services and industries, are hurting rural New South Wales. In many ways the hurt being felt in the bush is also being felt in the cities but the effects are slower due to marginally better employment opportunities and services in the city.

speech.para: The long-term effects of economic rationalist policies are being felt right across Australia with employment opportunities in rail, Telstra, the Roads and Traffic Authority, county councils and banks dwindling as we speak. The point the government is missing in the economic debate is that people go into business to create wealth, not to create jobs. Employment is only incidental to their business and profit is the main motive. There is no incentive for business to employ people; they only do this if it assists in the profitability of their company. In a balanced economy there is a role for government enterprise, private industry and small business to complement each other and maximise employment opportunities.

The social justice statement refers to the Commonwealth government's reduction of tariffs on imported orange juice to five per cent. Australian growers can no longer compete with Brazilian orange juice concentrate which is imported at $30 per tonne compared to local production costs of $200 per tonne. The document states that citrus growers in southern New South Wales are bulldozing and burning half a million healthy 40-year-old Valencia orange trees because they cannot afford to pick and sell the fruit. The point is made that the reduction in tariffs to five per cent can be contrasted with the fact that imports of Australian juice into Brazil are subject to a 40 per cent tariff.

An example is given in the document of the effects of a closure of a central service in country towns. The example relates to the closure of a bank in the northern New South Wales town of Mungindi. This town had one bank until August 1996 when one month's notice was given that it was being closed as a result of a feasibility study showing that it was unprofitable. Customers were told that their accounts would be transferred to Moree which is 120 kilometres away. A number of alternative methods of banking were tried for this town and currently a credit union is operating successfully, but business in Mungindi did suffer and people travelled to Moree to do their shopping and banking.

The statement also refers to the closure of the Cobar mine where 260 workers lost their jobs overnight. The workers were laid off with a month's wages and accrued annual leave still owing. The work force was owed approximately $9 million. The Ghana based Ashanti Goldfields refused to meet its legal commitment to its work force. Every business in Cobar felt the flow-on effects of this closure, with at least $1 million owing to local enterprises; 18 full-time workers at the brickworks were sacked as the mining company owed the brickworks $145,000; an engineering workshop was left with a bad debt of $90,000, forcing the retrenchment of five full-time workers and the jobs of the company trainees and apprentices also under threat; a local hardware store has been forced to lay off two full-time staff and three casuals; and cafes, corner stores and other retailers have cut casual staff. The most devastating effect that happened in Cobar also happens in metropolitan areas when a company closes its doors. The effect is not so immediate but the slow drip of insecurity starts immediately the company announces its decision to close its plant.

Take the case of Dow Corning which has begun a two-year phase-out of manufacturing operations at its Blacktown plant. About 40 employees will be affected by this decision. The company representative when asked how staff had reacted to the news said, `There was shock, surprise, distress and anxiety.'

I am sure this is the way many Australians are feeling today with this government being more interested in having a budget surplus than meeting its commitment to the unemployed, the aged and the young families, particularly those in rural Australia, whose plight is set out in the St Vincent de Paul Society's social justice statement.

subdebateinfo.title: Redland District Committee on the Ageing

talk.start.para: âRecently the Redland District Committee on the Ageing, or RDCOTA as it is most widely known, handed over the keys of a wonderful rehabilitation cottage, adjacent to the new Redlands Hospital, to the Queensland Department of Health. This unique cottage, the first of its kind in Queensland and the Redlands, has been designed and furnished to resemble the type of home a patient may return to when discharged from hospital care.

speech.para: RDCOTA has identified that the strongest motivating factor in rehabilitation is the patient's desire to go home. However, the strongest concern felt by most patients and carers is the fear of their inability to cope in the home situation.

RDCOTA is an independent, non-profit organisation that promotes the interests and wellbeing of citizens over the age of 50 within the Redland shire. RDCOTA was given the task of creating a rehabilitation haven that really encouraged rehabilitation. All too often hospitals create dependency due to their wide corridors, fittings for the handicapped, and the availability of constant help. While hospitals serve a definite purpose, they do not provide adequate settings for rehabilitation.

para.inline: A division having been called in the House of Representativesâ
Sitting suspended from 12.36 p.m. to 12.48 p.m.

talk.start.para: âBefore the suspension, I was talking about the RDCOTA cottage for rehabilitation. Catering for all ages, this is a fabulous facility for those patients who require rehabilitation services after injury or the onset of ageing afflictions such as stroke and acquired brain injury. The rehabilitation cottage provides the opportunity for patients and carers to adapt emotionally and physically to their changed health circumstances, in a relaxed, non-clinical atmosphere.

speech.para: I commend both Graham Hyde, regional director of South East Queensland Health, for his initiation of this project and the RDCOTA team for their dedication and commitment to seeing this project through in such an amazingly short time. Just to thank `the team' is not enough. Congratulations are due to each and every one of the RDCOTA president's advisory committee: Judy Tottle, chairman; Alla Cragie, secretary; Jack Rosa, treasurer; Clyde Gilmour, Ian Crane, Tony Sweeney, David Parr, Ron Loney, Dianne Edwards, Kath McNelly, Carolyn Santagiuliana, John Marsson and Albert Benfer.

I could not possibly list the names of all those who sponsored this project or contributed in some way, as funds and materials came from so many in the local community, but this is the single most impressive feature of this projectâthat the whole community was encouraged and actively engaged in contributing financially to this worthwhile project. This is a clear example of how partnerships can be forged between the local community, the health bureaucracy and a community organisation, all dedicated to getting this project up and running. I wish RDCOTA every success in the running of this fabulous rehabilitation centre and look forward to enjoying a strong working relationship with the organisation in the future.

The RDCOTA team have already shown such strong dedication and professionalism in bringing the concept of the cottage to fruition that I have no doubt the venture will enjoy every success. Their next project is the coordination of the community support for the International Year of the Older Person. Already it has all the semblance of continuing the successful record achieved by the completion of the rehabilitation cottage project. This being the case, I look forward to assisting the committee in the successful completion of this future community project.

talk.start.para: âBefore I call the next speaker I advise the committee that, due to the divisions, the adjournment debate will conclude at 1.12 p.m. I call the honourable member for Corio.

subdebateinfo.title: Job Placement, Employment and Training Program

talk.start.para: âOn 23 June I raised a matter in the House relating to the withdrawal of funding to a JPET program run by Create Geelong in my electorate. I raised at the time, when the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) was on duty in the House, some questions relating to why this funding has been withdrawn. I requested that the minister agree to meet with me to discuss the matter and to canvass ways in which that funding might be restored.

speech.para: It is a very successful program which is catering to young unemployed people in the northern part of my electorate. It is an area of extremely high unemployment. The rates of unemployment in the Corio and Norlane area are not only one of the highest in the state of Victoria, but they are as high as anywhere else around Australia. There is a very real need for the services of this JPET program because many of those unemployed people are young people who have been using this service, and using it successfully.

There are some very serious questions to be raised about the procedures which gave rise to the decision not to fund Create Geelong in the northern part of my electorate. This particular JPET program is run by a skillshare called Create Geelong which has a management committee comprising prominent community people in the northern part of my electorate. It has extensive support within the local community. Indeed, for the program that was funded previously there was a community contribution of around $90,000, which was matched by Commonwealth funding of about $130,000. So the local community has thrown its weight behind this particular program and, of course, the clientsâthe young people who have used this serviceâand their parents have written many letters to me asking why the service has been defunded, seeing that it has been such a successful one as far as outcomes are concerned.

The neighbouring electorate of Ballarat, which I put on the record once again, and which is a marginal Liberal seat, received JPET funding for two of their programs in areas where the level of general unemployment was not as high as the levels of unemployment in the Norlane and Corio areasâ

talk.start.para: âI wonder why that was?

âThe honourable member may ask why that is so. I think we have to look logically at what might be the reasons that the JPET program in Corio has not been funded. Interestingly enough, the JPET programs in Ballarat did not receive the same level of community contribution and support nor were they servicing the same number of clients for the money that was being put in by the Commonwealth and, indeed, the local community.

speech.para: I raise these questions on the floor of this committee because I am determined to get to the bottom of why this particular program has been defunded. The people who are being affected by this are young Australians who deserve an opportunity to improve their skills and to prepare themselves for a job market.

There are some rumours circulating within my community about why this program has been defunded. I have not been able to verify the rumours that are circulating, but I serve notice to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Mr Abbott), with whom I have a good relationship. I have raised this issue in all honesty with them, to give them an opportunity to restore the funding or to look for a way for the Commonwealth to fund the program. I will pursue this matter, because all is not well in the state of Denmark. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âSir Robert Menzies, the founder of the Liberal Party and our nation's longest serving Prime Minister, said many fine and well-founded things during his lifetime. It is just over 20 years since his death, but his inspiration proves timely. In the face of a lot of today's political agenda, I believe it is important to revisit Menzies' and therefore Liberal Party philosophy.

speech.para: Menzies chose the name `Liberal' deliberately. He saw our party not as a conservative party, although we contain conservative elements and engender the support of conservatives, but as a party of progress, a party which promotes worthwhile change, a truly liberal party.
At the Conference of Representatives of Non-Labour Organisations held in October 1944, which ultimately led to the formation of the Liberal Party, Menzies said:
There is no room for a party of reaction. There is no useful place for a policy of negation.
In Australia today, we certainly do not need opposition for opposition's sake.

There are those, of course, who would proffer an agenda which seems simple and, at first, perhaps acceptable. But this agenda is in fact quite out of keeping with the Australian way developed over a long period. The Australia of 1998 did not arrive because of foreign influence and conspiracy, but rather because of the values that Australians have always found acceptable; values for which Australians fought and died; values which have helped our nation stand out amongst all others in the world; values which have encouraged people from all parts of the world to come to be part of this nation; values which have shaped our nation into the egalitarian, generous, tolerant and responsible nation we are today.
As a nation, we have always been a people of the fair go, the Australian version of Martin Luther King's sentiment of judging no man by any criteria other than the calibre of his character.

Tough economic times do prevail as we move from the industrial age to the technology age, just as there were tough conditions when we moved from primary to secondary production. The false prophets offering the promised land have peppered the history of mankind. They come; they go. Often they come and they blame some innocent minority group for every social ill, every disease, every economic event. Such a blame mentality destroys the harmony of a society. Uttering ill will to others is an easy course to take the spotlight of inadequacy off oneself.

There is an inherent un-Australianness about those who seek to divide by race, creed, nationality or circumstance the various peoples which make up Australia. Not only is there no basis of fact to their claims but there is no acceptable philosophy other than the kind of nationalism made famous by Hitler in the 1920s and 1930s when middle of the road politicians were voted out in favour of populists in Germany.
On 13 October 1944, Menzies warned:
There is free thought and free speech and free association for all except the enemies of freedom.

Menzies understood that the enemies of freedom would take many forms. Menzies inspired the Liberal Party to set forth and create a nation where `citizens are free to choose their own way of living and of life'. Language ability or otherwise was not a barrier. Would we have denied Sir Arvi Parbo or Sir Gustav Nossal a place in Australia because of language? What about Taiwanese born Gordon Fu of MacGregor in my electorate? He has created hundreds of jobs in Brisbane through his shrewd business skills, yet English is not his strong point.

Sir Robert Menzies saw a nation `in which living standards rise steadily as physical resources expand and ingenuity grows'. In his speech of 1944, Menzies talked of thrift, enterprise and reward for effort. He talked of tax reform in order to help families. He talked of encouraging investment through the right types of monetary and other economic policyâmajor public policy not based on off the cuff pronouncements, but on an underlying logic.

There are a few racists in every country, but we are not a racist nation. Menzies never saw us this way, despite his own great love for his own motherlandâthe love that so many still hold for Great Britain, Ireland and Europe. All of that should be a ready example for others to understand that there would be just as much understandable affection for the land of any one person's family heritage. People from other countries are welcome here in Australia; they contribute to our common future.

In 1994, Menzies saw big government as authoritarian and dangerous. People these days expect government `to provide and do'. This reliance on government by so many Australians is probably the source of much of the angst at the moment. The Howard government is attempting to restart individualism in Australia, and, of course, many resist this. Likewise, government still has a way to go to withdraw from many of its unnecessary intrusions into our lives.

Menzies posed the challenges. He highlighted the principles for national success, which the Liberals and the Nationals under John Howard uphold today. Menzies said it for all of us on this side when he spoke without qualification or caveat, no exclusion along class, creed or colour lines. Menzies said what Australia is all about when he said:
I see the individual and his encouragement and recognition as the prime motive force for the building of a better world.
These are all matters worth standing up for and being counted for today. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âDuring the last couple of months, many in this House have been somewhat critical of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). I am reluctant to engage in this criticism because I believe it is only giving unnecessary publicity to an individual and a political party which, quite frankly, are not worth it. But I am somewhat amused at some comments attributed to the member for Oxley. The first is that she objects that too many tourists are coming here and they are doing so on prepaid trips.

speech.para: Depending on when the election is called, I intend to go overseas for a very short time during the parliamentary break. Like most sensible travellers, my accommodation will be prepaid because it is half the cost. Over 90 per cent of the thousands of Australian tourists who each year visit Asia do so on prepaid package deals. I suspect most members of parliament, unless they are on an official delegation, also prepay. I cannot see what the member for Oxley objects to. The money still pays for accommodation in Australia and it also contributes to the wages of Australian workers in the hospitality and tourist industry.

I note, too, that she objects to signs in languages other than English. Quite frankly, I am unaware of how frequently, if ever, the member for Oxley has been overseas. On the Tokyo metro system, all signs are in English and Japanese. As a frequent visitor to Tokyo, I am quite relieved about this. Last year I went to Kobe airport. I arrived there, and, by following signs in English, left the plane, got on a small transporter, went through customs and then on another transporter, then was directed to a bus, got on the bus, went to the harbour, got on the boat, went across on the boat, was met on the other side by a bus, went on the bus and was delivered to the hotelâall by following signs in English. There are Japanese and other signs as well.

Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, as you would be aware, Australians are not the world's leading linguists, but we are among the world's leading travellers. Surprisingly, our most travelled destinations are countries where Englishâor strineâis not the lingua franca. For many Australians, it is with a sense of relief when we see the signs `English spoken' or `Australian breakfast served'. Many of us like to think the world is becoming a smaller place and that international understanding is increasing. One way to achieve this aim is through travel. It may be a cliche to say that travel broadens the mind. It may be true; it may not be. But it certainly improves one's linguistic ability.

I would suggest to the member for Oxley that she reflect on some of her comments and realise that, just as we cannot close our borders to others, also we cannot retreat into a fortress Australia. We cannot increase our tariff barriers, because others will retaliate against us and we will all be the victims of such actions.

I suggest also that those vigilantes who want to white out signs with other languages on them, be they street signs or shop window signs, should think about it. What if this happened in other areas? What if, for instance, in Thailand, there were only signs in Thai, or in China only signs in Chinese, or in Chile only signs in Spanish? It would be very difficult for foreign visitors to those countries. I would hate to think of the terrible anguish and turmoil for Australian tourists overseas if this happened. How could they travel through Indonesia, Japan, Thailand, Korea, not to mention places like Kurdistan and Uzbekistan?

Perhaps One Nation's policy is to make it unlawful for any Australian, for any reason, ever to leave these shores. After all, according to One Nation we have it all here. Why go overseas to eat challenging foods? Why go overseas to listen to funny languages? Why go overseas to look at strange old buildings? Why go overseas to experience and explore cultures other than our own? We have it all here, we do not want to share it with anyone and we will fight to keep it. But if every nation took the same viewâno more tourism, no more foreign signs anywhereâwhy not go all the way and ban the learning of foreign languages? Is this what the member for Oxley wants? I suspect that she has not thought this matter through.

talk.start.para: âOn 30 June, it was my pleasure and honour, along with a number of my parliamentary colleagues, to attend a workshop entitled `Courts and the political arms of government'. The workshop was organised by the Judicial Conference of Australia with the purpose of providing a forum for members of the parliament and their judiciary to talk to each other about how constituent concerns might best be dealt with in matters such as Family Court cases, sentencing of offenders and the expression of community concerns about these and other matters.

speech.para: The forum also addressed the question of how access to justice can be improved. It was a privilege for me to attend the forum and to learn more about the work of the Judicial Conference. The conference is particularly concerned with the work of advancing a strong and independent judiciary through such activities as education of the public, communication with other arms of government, continuous improvement in the quality and accessibility to the judicial system and research which will benefit these aims.

I found the forum to be a particularly valuable exercise. All of us in this place from time to time have cause to deal with people who are experiencing the legal system as litigants, defendants or parties to Family Court matters. To these people the law can be a frightening and confusing structure, and as members of parliament we must often do our best to comfort and assist these people, without, of course, having the power to intervene directly where the courts are involved.

A forum of the sort that I was invited to attend is therefore extremely helpful because it equips us as members of parliament to explain to our constituents how they can go about assisting themselves within the legal system. The forum was also extremely useful from another standpoint; it provided me with an opportunity to bring to the attention of the members of the judiciary the concerns of my electorate of Makin. I would especially like to thank Professor Stephen Parker of Griffith University, who as secretary and treasurer of the Judicial Conference chaired the forum. As I said before, one of the aims of the Judicial Conference is to continuously improve the quality of and accessibility to the judicial system.

One very important aspect of the accessibility of the judicial system is that our citizens understand and have confidence in our courts and the work that they do. In particular it is important that our courts, while maintaining their independent role, are seen to be in touch with community views and standards. Indeed, one of the topics at the forum, as I said earlier, was entitled `The courts and community sentiment'. I took the opportunity to bring to the attention of the judges who were present the strong feeling in my electorate of Makin, and indeed throughout South Australia, about the release of prisoners who have not shown signs of rehabilitation and who continue to pose a threat to the community.

Recently I had cause to lodge a petition on this subject which I will shortly be submitting to the state parliament of South Australia. This petition calls for the safety of the community to be the paramount concern in decisions relating to sentencing and parole, particularly in relation to crimes such as paedophilia and other offences of similar magnitude. I think this petition will demonstrate to our state politicians and our judiciary the importance of our sentencing laws reflecting the very genuine concerns of the community. I believe it is my duty, not just as a member of parliament but as a member of my local community and a parent of three boys, to foster a healthy relationship between an independent judiciary and a community which feels safe and confident, and to take the community concerns direct not only to our state and local politicians but to our judges who are sentencing the criminals.
